case_vignette: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for worsening symptoms. The patient recently saw his pediatrician for an acute episode of sinusitis. At the time, the pediatrician prescribed decongestants and sent the patient home. Since then, the patient has developed a nasal discharge with worsening pain. The patient has a past medical history of asthma which is well controlled with albuterol. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/48 mmHg, pulse is 124/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you note a healthy young boy. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Inspection of the patient's nose reveals a unilateral purulent discharge mixed with blood. The rest of the patient's exam is within normal limits.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got a runny nose with pain that's getting worse, and sometimes there's blood mixed in with the yucky stuff coming out.
Have you had any fever or chills?
I feel a bit warm but not too hot; I don't think I've had the chills.
Have you had any cough or sore throat?
No, I haven't had a cough or sore throat.
Have you had any difficulty breathing or shortness of breath?
No, I haven't had trouble breathing or felt short of breath.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to anyone who has been sick?
No, I haven't traveled recently or been around someone who's sick.
Have you had any recent changes in your appetite or eating habits?
No, my eating habits haven't changed recently.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or sleep quality?
No, my sleep has been the same.
Have you had any recent changes in your activity level or exercise routine?
No, my activity level and exercise routine have stayed the same.
Have you had any recent changes in your stress or anxiety levels?
No, I haven't felt more stressed or anxious than usual.
Have you had any recent changes in your weight or body composition?
No, my weight has stayed the same.
Have you had any recent changes in your menstrual cycle or reproductive health?
I'm a little boy, so I don't have those things.
Have you had any recent changes in your vision or hearing?
No, my vision and hearing haven't changed.
Have you had any recent changes in your skin or nails?
No, my skin and nails have been the same.
Have you had any recent changes in your urine or bowel movements?
No, there haven't been any changes in my peeing or pooping.
Have you had any recent changes in your energy levels or fatigue?

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient has a runny nose with worsening pain, and sometimes there's blood mixed in with the nasal discharge. The patient also reports feeling a bit warm but not too hot, denying having chills, cough, sore throat, trouble breathing, or recent travel or exposure to sick individuals. The patient also denies recent changes in eating habits, sleep, activity level, stress, weight, vision, hearing, skin, nails, urination, or bowel movements.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is acute bacterial sinusitis with complications.
trial_0.singleturn_mcq: **Final Diagnosis:** Bleeding and infected vessel of Kiesselbach plexus.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely diagnosis is a viral upper respiratory infection (URI) with nasal congestion and occasional bleeding.
